Fields.DialogueText: How's the weather treating you, Kanchou?
I'm noticing the chill, but I'm pretty sure it won't kill me. You?
Samui no ga suki desu. It's perfect for me. There's a bite to the briskness that keeps you alert - like the air itself pinching you to keep you awake for her display.

Fields.MenuText: The air sounds boring if it's putting me to sleep.
I'd rather the air tuck me in with a cup of tea.
It's certainly refreshing. The interior of the ship gets so stuffy.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe you just need to know what to watch for. There's something to enjoy in every one of the wind's moods.
If the Kami could choose what the wind did, we wouldn't need engines.
Be glad I'm not a carrier. They're still working out the exhaust problems on those girls.
Not to mention lonely.
*ALARM*
Or ugliness.
There is beauty even in that... if you look very, very hard.
@BATTLE
Was it getting warm for you below?
Hard to be lonely with a complement of over two hundred.
You don't have to be alone to be lonely. I haven't yet found someone who appreciates my interests quite the way I do.
The weather?
French cinema, lately.
... Can you speak French?
I'm still learning. But you don't have to know the language to appreciate a visual medium.
I imagine it helps.
Just the way of things, Kanchou. Beneath every layer of understanding is a new kind of beauty.
Comment se passe votre journée? J'espère que vous n'êtes pas la bibliothèque. Si vous êtes, avez une crêpe.
Kasumi?
Oh! Good afternoon, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: I thought I heard someone talking about pancakes.
Practicing French?
Bon après-midi, I believe you mean.

Fields.DialogueText: Is that really what I was saying? Well, at least it was recognizable.
Trying to. Western languages are easier read than spoken.
Oh, you're full of surprises! Bon ap... how did that go again?
Cinema's one thing, but the French have such beautiful poetry as well. I'm trying to teach myself.
Oh, I do. Different languages render the message differently. Isn't that fascinating all on its own?
Theory's all well and good, but you need practice to learn a language conversationally.
Oh, I know. I just wouldn't want to be a bother. They signed up to fight for their country, not teach the ship French.
Are you kidding? Most sailors I know would jump at the opportunity.
I suppose we Kami are pretty special, aren't we? I sometimes forget how unusual we are.
@BATTLE
You don't want to read a translation?
The only trouble is that we have so few French crew, and all of them so busy.
I'm trying to. You're here to stay, and we're glad to have you.
Arigatō, Kanchou.
Oh! I mean... merci.
*ALARM*
Ah, the universal language.
The lingua franca, as they say...
Those are... a lot of charts, Kasumi.
Oh! Kanchou, I didn't see you there. Stacked these things too high, I suppose.
I'm surprised you can navigate.
Arigatō. I do have a curious tendency to lose charts while walking.

Fields.MenuText: What kind are they?
Any treasure maps there?
Do you need to carry that many all the time?

Fields.DialogueText: Nautical charts of our patrol route. I thought I'd look in on the navigators.
Just the regular kind. I'm not really interested in things buried, truth be told.
Strictly speaking, no. But the challenge excites me.
The navigation team's top notch, Kanchou. They could be working with better tools, though.
I can requisition more compasses and whatnot. Were they getting old?
Oh, no, I'm talking about the charts themselves. There were some irregularities in elevation. Nothing critical to our route around the Home Islands, of course, but-
How did you know the maps were off?
Pocket Tadataka. See? Always useful to have a benchmark.
That's a big atlas. Do you even have a pocket that can fit in?
Not the point. We're about a generation removed from the great Inō Tadataka's maps, but my country used them for a hundred years for a reason.
Are all of our charts... irregular?
Not by too terribly much, if that first one is anything to go by. I'll make it my project to bring them all in line.
@BATTLE
Oh, careful! Let me get that for you.
It's not a problem for me. I could walk the corridors from stem to stern in complete darkness. Quite comfortably, too.
*ALARM*
That's not a word.
Gah! There they all go. Gomen nasai, Kanchou. I startled when I should have... stoppled.
And yet you can infer its meaning. Isn't language fun?
More fun than gathering these charts alone. I'll help you.
Oh, this simply won't do.
Mapping troubles?
Well, they're actually quite accurate. But they just don't have the flair of an old Tadataka. See the mountains on this one?

Fields.MenuText: Accuracy is more important than beauty in a chart.
They're beautiful. You can almost picture yourself there.
Think you might spruce our charts up?

Fields.DialogueText: I agree, but they don't have to be  sterile.
It's easier to learn something that arouses passion. Tadataka was good at that.
It may be best to simply make my own. There isn't much space on these for an artistic flair.
Was there something you needed, Kanchou?
I wanted to report that we'll be changing course. We're receiving an SOS from south of Tanegashima Island.
A journey of three hours or so. Though I'm sensing a complication.
A few complications. All of them Morgana-shaped.
Nothing's ever easy. Well, what are we waiting for? All ahead full.
@BATTLE
That bad, huh?
Today's surveyors just don't have the attention to detail Tadataka did.
I hate being interrupted. Better to come to a stopping point and deal with the enemy on my terms.
You don't have to put that away right now. They're still a ways off.
You've certainly made a lot of progress.
Enough progress. The solitude was starting to gnaw at me.
There! Do you see the smoke?
And a whole lot of wreckage. Looks like we got here too late.
Do you think there are any survivors?

Fields.MenuText: I certainly hope so. We need to look for anyone who might have made it.
There have to be. We got here as fast as we could.
Highly unlikely. You know how Morganas operate.

Fields.DialogueText: I wish I could banish smoke the way I can banish Morgana mist. Visibility is terrible.
There's more to this than we know, Kanchou. We'll find someone.
I do. I also know that even they can make mistakes.
I can't believe any civilians are still out here. Don't they know the risk?
Not adequately. There was a lot of interference on their end.
Typical Funayūrei. If there's a purpose to them, it's to keep you humans divided.
But why?
It's harder to achieve greatness when you're fighting for survival. And nobody does it alone. I certainly don't.
@BATTLE
I thought civilian transport had been pressed into the war effort. Did they identify themselves?
Nor will you. We're not letting them get away with this.
Hai. There are few forces as inseparable as a Kami and her kanchou.
Captain! We've got a live one. He's hurt, but he'll pull through.
Thank goodness. Get him on board and patched up.
And quickly. I think the Funayūrei know their victory was incomplete.
Welcome aboard. How're you holding up?
Are you all right? You're not too badly injured, are you? What's your name?
Non, I am not. Call me... Renoir.
Are there any other survivors?
I don't know. I did not see anyone else - the smoke was too thick.
We'll make sure to sweep the area.
What happened?
We were attacked.
*ALARM*
They're coming for their prize. Kanchou, let's do our duty!
@BATTLE
Some of them. Our surveillance hasn't detected any other survivors, either.
Our new friend is likely the only one remaining.
Sir, are you smiling?
Make no mistake. I'm absolutely torn up inside. But the fact that I'm alive... I'm not sure. I'm just filled with all manner of emotions.
You're safe now. That's what matters. We'll set you up somewhere for now.

Fields.MenuText: Suspicious...
He's certainly a charmer.
He's happy to be alive. I would be too.

Fields.DialogueText: War is unpredictable. We all have different ways of shutting out the trauma.
A shame it doesn't work on the Funayūrei.
A smile is a valuable thing in these times.
Well, obviously.
Were those the Morganas that attacked the civilian ship?
Merci, my spectral friend. Just until I can secure passage to France in a friendly port.
He's also French. Had you noticed?
Oui, Capitaine. I suspect he and I will have much to discuss.
How is our survivor, Kasumi?
He's still resting, Kanchou. The rush of survival seems to have worn off.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think of him?
There's just something weird about him. I can't shake the feeling.
Who do you think he is?

Fields.DialogueText: He seemed interesting. I'll have to talk to him more when he decides he's rested enough.
I'd be wary of anyone who's the same person on and off the battlefield.
We won't know until he's up and talking. If only that distress call hadn't been garbled.
I do have a few questions for him once he's well.
Language lessons?
Perhaps. Do you go to the movies, Kanchou? Have you seen any French films?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not much of a cinema person, if we're being honest.

Fields.DialogueText: There's a French director, a very good one, named Jean Renoir. What if our survivor is the same Jean Renoir?
How in the world would that be possible?
It's outlandish, I know. But we were able to recover Renoir's belongings from the lifeboat he was in.
We found some reels of film among them. One of them bore his name.
Even if I accept this incredible theory, why would he be here?
We'll just need to ask him once he wakes up!
@BATTLE
You do love a good mystery, don't you?
You can never see every side of something right away. You've got to turn it over and over until you've divined its secrets.
*ALARM*
Well, we'll see. Show me the inside of these Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Quite a few. Why do you ask?

Fields.DialogueText: Bonjour, Capitaine, Mademoiselle Kasumi.
Bonjour, Monsieur Renoir!
I'm happy to see that you're awake.
It's nice to be awake. How long was I out?
Not so very long, Renoir-san. You've had a rough journey.
Mon Dieu. Such an awful sound.
Hai. It's about to get rougher, unfortunately. Do hold on to something.
Remain in your quarters. I assure you, we have everything under control.
@BATTLE
Do those attacks happen often?

Fields.MenuText: Too often. The seas are a madhouse.
You get used to it.
As often as they need to. We're fighting the good fight.

Fields.DialogueText: I respect your distinguished service. I would think once is too many!
Remarkable what the human spirit will endure.
You're braver than I would ever be! Ah, but we are not all of us made warriors.
That's what we're out here for. We'll put them back where they belong.
Wherever that might be.
*ALARM*
In the meantime, if you don't mind me asking...
A ship spirit is curious about a lowly human? Ask away.
Of course. Humans are so interesting. You are French, are you not?
Oui, as French as the sun is hot.
I'm... actually trying to pick up the language myself. Might we converse now and again?
Bien sûr! Je suis heureux de parler.
Merveilleux! Il pleut des pommes de terre.
Ha! Not a bad accent. We'll work on your vocabulary.
Renoir?
Are you Jean Renoir!?
... Returning to the question I had intended to ask...
I hate to disappoint you, ma chérie, but I am not Jean Renoir.
Sumimasen. I intended no disrespect.
Jean is my brother. My first name is Pierre.
Oh!
But please, continue calling me Renoir. It is the name I'm most frequently addressed by.
Where were you travelling, Renoir?
I was transporting some film reels for my brother and a friend. Speaking of which, where are...
Your personal belongings are safe.
Oh, wonderful. There should be a briefcase and some film reels, yes?
Hai! We recovered all of them from the lifeboat. Everything is safe.

Fields.MenuText: You may be the luckiest man I've ever met.
You're alive. That's what matters.
Those film reels must be very important.

Fields.DialogueText: Luck is a process, non? We will see how lucky I am if I don't get these reels to my brother!
Well, sure. Until my brother found out I lost the reels and killed me himself!
Very important! My whole livelihood may rest upon them. And my life, if my brother is to be believed.
When the boat began to sink, I grabbed what I could. Still, I fear I left behind more than I would have liked. My only clothes are what I have on my back, par exemple.
I'm sure I missed some of the film reels, as well. There were so many on board that ship. And now they're all gone.
... I owe you everything, and yet I must ask one more thing of you. Do not tell the crew who I am. International cooperation is a wonderful thing, but I can do without being pestered by film fans.
I'm sure that won't be a problem. Right, Kasumi?
Ah, Capitaine! I was taking in the air just now.
Glad you're up and about. Well, glad you're up, in any event. I was wondering if you could tell us-
Bonjour et ohayo!
Mochiron. You know, I adored you in Madame Bovary.
Not a problem at all.
Oh! We've got problems of our own, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I didn't know you were such a big fan of film, Kasumi.
It's not just film, it's French film. Something about it is just so... magical. I can't tell if it's the films themselves or if it's my obsession with the language.
Or both?
Hai. A little from column A, a little from column B.

Fields.MenuText: How did the obsession start?
Why not a different language?
Is it just film, or French art in general?

Fields.DialogueText: I stumbled into a screening of Madame Bovary at the Naval Training Center. The rest is history.
I don't really question it. You might as well ask why I'm fluent in Dutch and English.
Everything that involves the French language, really. Scratch the surface and you get hungry for what's beneath.
Honestly, if this whole war wasn't going on, I would much rather spend my time drinking tea and watching French films.
Opportunity's knocked with our guest, hasn't it?
So far that may be the one thing I dislike about him. He doesn't like tea.
No! Really?
Eau de feuille, he calls it. Leaf water.
*ALARM*
Sometimes you learn the most from those you like the least.
@BATTLE
He's not technically wrong.
Ugh! That's the worst way to be right! And all the coffee he drinks only makes him more energetic in his... worstness.
Having said that, he's excellent conversation and I'm grateful for the opportunity to practice his language.
If only to figure out how their pieces come apart.
Bonjour!
Bonjour!
Parlez-vous français?
Juste un peu!

Fields.MenuText: C'était plutôt bien, Kasumi. Vos voyelles sont excellentes!
Is now a bad time?
What's the French for "tea isn't so bad?"

Fields.DialogueText: Nani? Ah... oui. Merci beaucoup, Capitaine!
Certainement pas. You should join us!
That's the other thing he's graciously asked me never to say.
We were just warming up to discuss current events.
You're that well versed in the language already?
It's the most remarkable thing, Capitaine. She's had her stumbles like anyone, but she is a natural student. Perhaps it is something to do with the Belles and their affinity for mankind.
Speaking of things taken, I haven't seen the usual newspaper this week. Did either of you borrow it?
Pah! I've no use for the news. Whatever the men in power want you to read, that's what they print. It's the same as anywhere.
Strange. Maybe it's just a fluke.
Perhaps Mademoiselle Kasumi might ask her ugly stepsisters?
Oh, stop it! You'll throw off my aim.
@BATTLE
Oui. Mes excuses. I see how that might have been taken incorrectly.
She's probably the best of my crew, human or otherwise.
Oh, Renoir was only paying a compliment. Weren't you, Renoir?
Haven't touched it. Renoir?
*ALARM*
There you two are! I knew if I found one of you, the other wouldn't be far away.
Guilty as charged.
I am here to invite you to dinner. It's my way of saying thanks.

Fields.MenuText: A dinner? Cooked by you?
That really isn't necessary, Renoir. Helping others is what we do.
I'm... busy, I'm afraid.

Fields.DialogueText: Absolutely! I'm not leaving this ship without properly thanking you for your rescue.
And rewarding generosity is what I do.
I haven't even told you the time or date of the dinner, Captain. Rest assured, I'll find a time that works with your schedule.
It will be my way of thanking you for your hospitality and, of course, saving my life.
That sounds absolutely delightful, Renoir!
I've already spoken with the ship's chef, and we have all the ingredients I need to make you two the best food you've had in months!
The two of you decide on a time which will work best, and let me know. I assure you - you're in for a treat.
He's certainly made friends, hasn't he?
For someone who wants his identity kept a secret, he sure is out and about.
That may not be so counterintuitive. Play your cards close to the chest and people will wonder what you're holding.
Why, that reminds me - I've been meaning to ask the helmsman how his family's doing. Jusqu'à la prochaine fois.
Hiding in plain sight, eh?
You don't think he's really hiding something, do you? Besides the obvious.
There's no way of knowing. But I want to know who he's talking to and what about. Loose lips sink ships.
Oh, ha ha.
Sorry. Was that insensitive?
No. It just wasn't very funny.
*ALARM*
Now these ships we can sink.
@BATTLE
Ah, Mademoiselle Kasumi! Fancy seeing you here.
Renoir! I didn't expect to see you above. These waters are dangerous.
I couldn't resist taking in the air. It is... how would one describe it? Sharp... chill...
Don't you think you were a little harsh on him?
Of course not. I'm not going to be responsible for civilian casualties. Frankly, I'm surprised he's even still aboard.
I've spoken to him about that. He can't write anyone without revealing the presence of a French VIP on an Imperial vessel. And there's no safe way to escort him to a neutral port.
No good deed goes unpunished, it seems.
Let me clarify, Kanchou. Don't be so harsh on him. It might make him suspicious.
He's suspicious enough.
Exactly. Did you notice how he slipped the patrols to get up here? He even surprised me.

Fields.MenuText: He's observant. But what is he looking for?

Fields.DialogueText: A way out. I suspect our actor may be acting.
At last we agree. I just wish we had proof.
That shouldn't be a problem. You heard us talking art, I trust.
That's what's so frustrating. He's done his research.
Not enough, Kanchou. Pont-Neuf depicts a summer scene.
Well, I'll be. Looks like your obsession came in handy. It could just be an honest mistake, of course.
Maybe. But we've found a field we can beat him on. It's just a matter of getting him there again.
Brisk?
Précisément. It is the sort of scene my father would have painted.
It does remind one of his Pont-Neuf, does it not? In all the deceptive chill of its bright winter's day.
Why, indeed. I am in the presence of a Renoir connoisseur!
*ALARM*
Renoir, what are you doing up here? We can't have civilians on deck, least of all going into an engagement!
Bien sûr, Capitaine. I shall defer to your judgment.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Good eye. I hadn't even caught that.

Fields.DialogueText: Though I'm not convinced he couldn't have just talked his way up here.

Fields.MenuText: A destroyer shouldn't be so easily surprised.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm on to him, Kanchou. Even if I do enjoy his company.
You've been at these maps all day. I thought you might have come to pester me or Renoir by now.
They've been keeping me busy. I haven't been as restless as I usually get.
I will give our guest credit, Kanchou. Whoever he is, he's got a way with words. Especially the French ones.

Fields.MenuText: Don't let your guard down.
You've certainly been getting a lot of practice in.
What if he really is who he says he is?

Fields.DialogueText: Kesshite. I'm keeping a much closer eye on him these days.
I admit he's frustratingly good conversation.
It's better to be wrong and safe than wrong and sinking.
A shame we can't just deposit him in the next port.
I'm not. Whether or not he's who he says he is, the Imperial Navy will have questions about why a Westerner was given free rein of the ship and subsequently turned loose.
Even a charming one?
Especially a charming one. The Emperor's servants should not be so easily swayed.
It's a breach we can only fill with our own heads.
Unless we allow him to sail through it.
It is exciting, isn't it? A high-stakes spy thriller in the midst of war? Our very own Second Bureau.
Another French film?
That's what happens when you stay busy.
I'm still on the fence about that.
Not until we know who he is and where he's going.
*ALARM*
Perhaps I'll have to ask Renoir if it's among his film reels. I'll bother him after the battle's won.
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitaine, a pleasure to see you!
Renoir. I hope we're not keeping you from anything important.
The world's navies may be cooperating, but Japan will have its own questions about your extended stay.
Have you now?
I found it among my film reels. It's a film I spent many months working on. I wrote the screenplay and directed it. None have seen it but its editor and I.
Secure a projector. Watch me. I will recite the film word for word. Mademoiselle Kasumi can vouch for my extraordinary memory.

Fields.MenuText: I have certain misgivings about judging you by a challenge you've set.
I'd really like to see that.
That must be a useful skill for an actor.

Fields.DialogueText: At the very least, I owe my rescuers a display of skill. My more material assets are mislaid at sea, you understand.
Speaking of things mislaid... did you ever solve the mystery of the missing newspaper?
I hadn't, actually.
Shame. I'll keep an eye out. It's the least I can do.
@BATTLE
Ah, it is certainly a shame I cannot more easily return to my beloved France.
Oui. I'm sorry to have been a bother. I realize as well that I have no way of proving my identity to you.
Indeed. With that in mind-
I may have found a way to put your suspicion to rest.
What does that have to do with your identity?
As should you. That is why you are the capitaine.
Anyone can recite lines. To truly deliver them is a different skill entirely.
I will make it a performance not to be forgotten!
*ALARM*
Dinner and a movie. Not a bad way to spend an evening.
If you survive that long. For all our sakes, please do.
Well? Criticize it. Tear it to pieces.
Oh, I'm going to tear this cassoulet to pieces, all right! Renoir, c'est délicieux!
A taste of home.

Fields.MenuText: Where in France did you say you were from?
It's quite good. Where did you learn to make this?
I can hardly focus on it. The film is all I can think about.

Fields.DialogueText: Why, Paris, of course! The beating heart of Europe herself.
My mother, rest her soul. A wizard in the kitchen. France has never known her equal!
In good time, Capitaine, in good time. No feat of memory was ever performed on an empty stomach.
Where did you find the projector, anyway?
Blame me, Kanchou. I've had one lying around since our tour began, just waiting to be put to use.
On the off chance that a mysterious Frenchman would wash aboard with a stack of his films.
That is the idea, militarily speaking.
If the kanchou were to let go of me, that would spell a watery grave for all of us.
*ALARM*
Well, not on that precise off chance.
The girl believes in magic! Hold on to this one, eh, Capitaine?
Ah, saved by the bell.
Pah. Not in a mood for comedy, I see. Well, luckily for us all, tonight's offering is a heartrending tragedy by the name of-
Stay below, Renoir, where it's safe. I can hardly wait!
@BATTLE
You have to admit, that was a breathtaking performance.
I still can't believe he had the whole thing committed to memory.
Isn't he a terrific actor?

Fields.MenuText: He's pretty good. I've seen better, though.
He's acting, all right.
I was watching him more than the screen.

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't lived as long as you have, Kanchou. I hope I see half of what you've seen by the time I do.
You need to stop and smell the roses, Kanchou. Skill does not stop being skill just because its practitioner may be up to no good.
Hai! So was I! And yet I was able to follow everything. Such range...
He's certainly kept me guessing. That's talent for you.
It does lend credence to the Pierre Renoir persona.
Maybe he is who he says he is. Who memorizes an entire film in case he's made to identify himself?
Walk with me to the bridge, Kanchou? I've been at these maps for quite long enough.
Of course. I need someone to process that bit of dinner theatre with.
Then again, who spends seventeen years mapping the Home Islands to the tiniest degree? Some men have little else to do but obsess.
Or they're just really good at it.
It's easiest to learn something that arouses passion. I believe everyone has something they would devote their whole being to, if only they could find it.
Speaking of finding things... what's this? Someone just left a newspaper here at the hatch.
Wait, that date... Isn't this the one you lost?
It went missing. There's a difference.
Kanchou, that headline...
"Prisoner Transport Convoy Ambushed." South of-
Tanegashima Island.
*ALARM*
Where's Renoir?
In his quarters. I can sense him.
See that he stays there.
Ryōkai.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, please let me confront him.
I'm the highest authority aboard this ship. He answers to me.
Highest authority? I'm the Emperor's will made flesh!

Fields.MenuText: That's debatable.
And you chose me to command you.
You go first, then.

Fields.DialogueText: This is neither the time nor the place to discuss theology.
I chose you for a partnership, Kanchou. Don't mistake our bond.
He's a human, I'm a Kami. He poses no threat to my person.
We don't know who he is or what he's capable of. At the very least, confront him from behind someone who can take a bullet.
Fine. But I get to knock.
You'll find the door to my quarters unlocked, once our hostess sees fit to unseal it.
Ah, Renoir. You look comfortable. And you sound less French than usual.
Read the news lately, Captain?
Right where you left it. And here I thought you had no use for it.
I don't. It's a tool like any other. But better to have the hammer in my hand than on my head. And speaking of head shots...
"An Evening with Pierre Renoir..." in London.
You don't have a good side!
So you stole the newspaper that would have told us you were a convict.
@BATTLE
You're the one who brought it up.
They didn't get my good side.
All I needed was time. Time to memorize the patrols... time to learn the lifeboat release mechanisms... time to plot my escape. The lady was a big help, weren't you, Kassie?
Kanchou, I swear-
*ALARM*
We don't have time for this. You're staying right here. Kasumi will keep your quarters sealed.
Peachy. I've got all the time in the world.
What did he mean, you were a big help?
Please understand, Kanchou, I would never betray you. I would never betray the Empire!
He was so... frustratingly charming, Kanchou. He really is fluent in French, and a moviegoer to boot. That's probably what led him to steal those film reels in Hanoi.
Nothing... happened... between us. But after a while, he started wanting me to teach him things, in exchange for the French lessons. And he was especially interested in cartography.

Fields.MenuText: He's a mapmaker, too? What a Renaissance man.
And all this time he was planning an escape route on those very maps!
He should have had you teach him cooking, too.

Fields.DialogueText: A map reader. Specifically of maps that get him to the mainland.
Accurate ones, too. An idiot could navigate with them.
It's all right to admit you liked his cooking. Kaigun kare's about all I know how to make, and anyone can do that.
Zettai chigau! Kanchou, they are not ours to burn! And besides... that film he screened...
We've got a war to win. We don't need a movie holding us up.
We've already aided and abetted a criminal. I'm not destroying what belongs to his victims. One sin does not undo another.
It's worked out well enough for him. If we turn him over to the IJN he's telling them all about the VIP treatment he's gotten. Then we're really in trouble.
@BATTLE
So he wants to sell those film reels. Why can't we just burn them?
I know. I think that's literally impossible anyway. But I need to know what he was talking about.
Before he got picked up for smuggling. Passion makes things easy, eh?
*ALARM*
We're in trouble now, Kanchou.
We'll deal with him later, then. He's right where we left him.
Gallingly far from my magazine.
You wouldn't.
I wouldn't. But the thought intruded.
So we're agreed. You go free, and not a word of any of this to the IJN.
Man of my word, Captain. Nothing like a little honor among thieves, eh?

Fields.MenuText: Don't try and pin this on us.
At least it's some kind of honor.
I'm starting to miss your French accent.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm pinning nothing. But the last time I checked, ignorance of the law was no excuse. I'm living proof of that.
There are so many different kinds! A man in my profession should collect them all.
I'm sorry to hear that. Transatlantic happens to be my favorite.
Rowing distance of the island you found me near. That's all I need. Then you never have to worry about me again.
Don't look at me like that.
You've got blood on your knuckles.
Just doing my duty.
I wasn't aware that was in the job description.
And a good one at that. I'll have to return the favor once we've carried out the plan.
What plan?
Wasureteta! I hadn't told you. Behold!
Shame. I could tell how excited you were to walk me through this.
@BATTLE
Fine. The sooner you and your reels are off the ship, the better.
I'll be sad to see you disappear over the horizon. Especially Kassie. Whip-smart, that one. You know, I've always had a thing for-
*WHUD*
Her name is Kasumi. You'll address her as such. Unless you want her to reiterate the point I just made.
Nope. Got it. All over my shirt. Ow...
Not as a captain. As a friend.
There will be other times. I'll roll the map up.
*ALARM*
... And un-behold.
And there's the lifeboat you're going to slip off with in the confusion.
Assuming we survive the battle.
Let us worry about that. You worry about being the man who got away from the IJN and the fleets of mankind in general.
@BATTLE
There he goes.
Take a guy to dinner before you make those kinds of promises, Captain. People will talk.

Fields.MenuText: But you won't. Or else.
I'm tempted to throw you overboard right now.
You'd like that, wouldn't you?

Fields.DialogueText: The tragedy of a con man. He can never tell his own best stories.
Loose lips sink ships, and you know what captains do when ships sink.
The talking or the dinner? Well, I wouldn't say no to either one, if the Belle's buying.
Reckon my life would have turned out different if I couldn't.
I'll give you this. You made us want to believe you.
Maybe you wouldn't have been arrested.
I knew I liked you. One day we'll all look back on this and laugh.
*ALARM*
On that I think we can agree.
I miss him already.
Ugh. I don't.
You sure?
I miss what he brought to the ship. The language... the conversation... He really did love to talk about French films, you know, not just steal them. There's no faking that.
It seems anything can be faked by the right person.
Funny you should mention that, Kanchou. I never did get around to explaining my plan, did I?
What's funny?
What would you say to another movie night?
You know, that movie's better when a con man's not talking through it.
Hmm. Well, his performance had a certain... je ne sais quoi.

Fields.MenuText: He teach you that?

Fields.DialogueText: And a few other tools of the trade besides.
So what was in those canisters he left with?

Fields.MenuText: What's that mean?
There was something captivating about it.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know what.
Waiting for him to mess up, only for him not to? I concur.
Then why did you say it?
I've got more lifeboats, you know.
A little something I've been working on almost since the tour started.
... All of them?
Do you know you can only fold paper so many times? I'm an Asashio-class and I could only manage seven.
At least he won't have any trouble finding his way to land.
If he ever gets to the Sea of Okhotsk.
... Remind me never to cross you.
Well, I wasn't going to use all of my charts. And I really liked the Kagoshima Prefecture one he's paddling through right now.
Any reason other than spite?
I'm really proud of the mountains I drew on it.
So am I, Kasumi. So am I.
Was it really a new one?
I'm not a cinema person. Maybe he'd stolen the only copy of one yet to be released.
Any word from Command?
That's our story and we're sticking to it?
We did let him go in a known hot zone with the wrong maps. I believe it.
It's still a lie.

Fields.MenuText: It's not a lie if you believe it.
No more of a lie than stranding him in southern waters with northern maps.
A convenient one.

Fields.DialogueText: I just wonder how long it will take to forget the truth.
It was a good idea. That doesn't make it the right one.
I'm sure he thought a life of crime was convenient.
Ignore right or wrong just for a moment. You're not going to let this incident define you.
You can never see every side of something right away, Kanchou. You've got to turn it over and over until you've divined its secrets. But what if you don't like what you see?
I see someone who extended a helping hand to someone in need. Biting it was his business. Those who won't... what you did just might have ensured we'll be around to help them.
*ALARM*
They express their regret that our prisoner escaped. As well as his untimely demise at the hands of the Morganas.
But what do I know? I'm just an accomplice.
Partner in crime.
I like the sound of that. Do you?
Tabun. I admit it's got the potential to grow on me.
@BATTLE
So walk me through what we just watched.
They stormed the palace, they beat the Prussians and whatnot. I got that far.
I recognized the French national anthem! That's what the film's named after.

Fields.MenuText: How much did Renoir really teach you?
Would you call this one your favorite?
I got the gist of it, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: Beaucoup. But it's a bit of a leap from casual conversation to historical drama.
I'm still a Madame Bovary girl through and through. But this one has its moments.
It was definitely stirring, Kanchou. Even if I couldn't really tell who was who. I don't think every character really existed.
I think I can guess what you liked most about the movie.
Seeing Renoir taken down a peg?
So it's set during the French Revolution.
Pierre Renoir as Louis XVI... now there's the role of a lifetime.
It doesn't really feel fair to point and laugh at the real Pierre. We've never met him.
And if we do meet him, we won't laugh. But we can enjoy the last laugh, can't we?
Indeed. But the night is still young. I believe there's one more reel we hadn't watched.
I'll miss these movie nights. But they're not ours to keep. Best to turn them over to the government. Now that we've verified their condition, you see.
All right, let me just get this threaded...
I don't hear anything. Is this a silent film?
Kanchou! Those... are those Morganas?
When was this taken?
Is this... is this footage from aboard the prisoner transport ship?
We'd have to have someone look at it and make sure.
*ALARM*
I think Command will be very interested in up-close footage of a  Morgana attack.
More than I am, Kanchou. We have season tickets.
@BATTLE
I knew you'd get used to it, Kanchou.
I guess I've been so focused on the movie madness I forgot to let the temperature get to me.
I wouldn't question it. It's convenient. That counts for a lot.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think of the footage?
You're defending the world and the people in it. Never forget that.
The journey down a road of crime begins with a single step.

Fields.DialogueText: I think whoever filmed it was both extremely lucky and extremely unlucky. It will serve a purpose... maybe even the one he anticipated it might.
That shouldn't have to mean protecting some people and not others. But I suppose this problem is something you humans have dealt with longer than I have.
It wasn't a step so much as a kick. That counts for something.
We've added another layer of understanding, Kanchou. Or peeled one back.
Do you like what you see?
I like aspects of it. Renoir did teach me some French poetry, you know. That part of me that helped a man in need... that wanted to see the beauty he saw in the world...
That's the part I really like. Why don't you listen to her?
It's hard sometimes, when the world calls for fighting and fire. But you're making it easier, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: What are friends for?
What can I say? You bring out the best in me.

Fields.DialogueText: Sitting down for a pot of tea and a little Renoir once the smoke clears?
Vous faites ressortir le meilleur de moi.
Is that the French for what I said?
The real one, this time.
Lovely day out, isn't it?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Close enough. I mean it too.
